comments.commentBody:
Educators have a huge problem on their hands. There is a huge difference between sheer memorization of a tremendous amount of data and actually knowing how to use that data. Medical school has long emphasized the former to the utter detriment of the latter, because licensing and specialty board exams are basically tests of rapid recitation with some multiple choice alternatives tossed in for the sake of increased difficulty and confusion. At that rate, the ideal doctor should be a computer. Unfortunately too much sheer data recall seems to cause a fair degree of inability to think things through logically, leading to great prosperity for lawyers specializing in - you guessed it - medical malpractice.
In this computer-driven age more and more exams in many subjects are multiple choice guessing contests graded by computer - and even math exams require one to enter the problem's solution in an exact and strictly timed format, making it possible to get all the right answers and still fail for lack of ability to perform data entry with sufficient dexterity and speed. If the goal is to turn students into robot-like performers they'll certainly accomplish it, but how much can you expect the many problems in the real world to be solved by robots?

I hear tell from GOP sources close to the Everglades that your theory about Germany may have a lick of credibility. Ever since Frau Merkel has reintroduced the goose step to  business schools, I've had the same fear as you.

Would you please elaborate the "german threats regarding compliance" when Angela Merkel did "dictate" anything to anybody?

The transaction tax was supposed to be installed in all the EU including germany/frankfurt, so stating that "the removal of both institutions to Frankfurt is the true aim of Frau Merkel" seems anglo-saxon fear mongering, fuelled by the banking industries advocacy groups, at it's best!

Also the true aim of "european dominance" seems at least as far fetched as the idea that germany put greece in a straight jacket. Afaik greece put itself into this situation and got plenty of help from banksters willing to help in forging their books.

Finally, you seem to forget that the german government is not only speaking for herself and it's citizens, but also for some other smaller northern neighbors very much agreeing in the current austrity approach.

And as an sincere advice from europe: don't hold your breath waiting for the € to "implode"... it won't!

On the European front, in which you have demonstrated a growing interest both on the front page and on your blog, I will complement you on some of your remarks on the subject; the fact is that Americans have a difficult time understanding the real overwhelming power of Germany in the debate ongoing there. Their inherent fear of inflation, given their history, their threats regarding compliance to their wishes, and Chancellor Merkels needed deference to her shaky coalition, all play a part in how they dictate, and they certainly do, how they wish to proceed.

David Cameron declined to allow the financial transaction tax to be imposed on The City, and Mr Kenny, the Irish Prime Minister, did the same on the Irish equivalent this past week, since both realize that the removal of both institutions to Frankfurt is the true aim of Frau Merkel. Dominance of Europe is still the ambition of the Germans. They now have the Greeks in a straight jacket with no where to turn.

As yet, there is no comparison between the Euro situation and that of the US, except that President Obama and the Federal Reserve have made an unknown number of billions of dollars available to the ECB without making the details known to the taxpayers of the US. What is the exposure of the US in this situation? If there is a well informed commentator on the facts of US exposure, and the least favorable outcome for the US, should the Euro implode, which many there expect, please inform me and the readers of the NYT.

I'am always a little bit surprised that conservatives don't see hedge fund managers (like that guy who rented the big house in the Hamptons and threw the wild parties) as more of a threat to the free market and the country than government spending money on the social safety net.

Even Rupert Murdoch has written: "Romney tax uses long-term legal loophole. 'carried interest' makes all fund managers rich. Time both parties stopped selling out to Wall S"

C'mon GOP, Rupert Murdoch is not a socialist.
The existing support for the Republican philosophy is what is so frightening. Listening to their debates  and accompaning audience responses makes me shutter,

Central planning must be abandoned. The federal government has grown too large and incompetent and it must be reduced in size. We have to abandon the false left-right paradigm that the elites have most American sheeple believing. Both parties are the same. They are all puppets to their criminal Federal Reserve masters.

Obama must explain in plain language to the population exactly why we cannot survive another Republican administration..
.

I think that the policies that Republicans champion border on evil They are based on greed, division,caste,conflict, the equation of monetary wealth with moral worth, demonetization, misinformation, and the perpetuation of the mythology of the uber rich as some kind of inherently superior of masters who as supplicants we need to be dependent upon for out survival. They want to punish the poor, the sick and the vulnerable as collateral damage in the economic societal law of the jungle they envision society to be,as a drain on our resources. They are also race baiters who want to frame blacks and other ethnic groups as being a drain on society and its resources.

It is not only the economic policies that need to be rejected, but also the philosophical belief systems that form the foundation from which these policies are created. He needs to unmask and explain the Orwellian mind games that the GOP has played to get millions of Americans to enter into a political sadomasochistic relationship with them making them vulnerable to misleading propaganda and vote for policies that make them poorer.

2102 is a much about our philosophy of who we as a society are as the policies we pursue because the former is the foundation of the latter. The GOP has gotten millions to accept a nihilistic belief system based upon economic myths, race and class division.

Who exactly it is a good idea for?

In the end, somebody has to pay for people who use heatlhcare services. If everybody pays less when they are young, they will have to pay more when they are older. Cheaper premiums for you mean more for someone else. If doctors and hospitals make less money doing routine care, because people are using less, it stands to reason they will charge more for catastrophic care.

What are the drivers of the cost of healthcare? Teaching hospitals often have higher costs, but from the people I know, the doctors working at prestigious hospitals don't make huge salaries. I believe a doctors can make more working in rural Texas than at a prestigious hospital in Boston. So where is the money going?

Some of it goes to more advanced equipment.
Supposedly outcomes aren't better at these hospitals, but there are certain situations where you can only get treated at those hospitals. For example, not every hospital has a level 3 NICU. If your baby doesn't need one, that's fine, but if they do, that is where you would want to go.

Well put!  The irony of American "exceptionalism" is there is, by and large, not much exceptional.  Cheating in high schools is rampant along with a troubling article that describes how big college sports trumps academics.  Let's be honest, kids coming out of college, can't write, speak or prepare meaningful analysis.  So, on point comments, I just had to add more spice.

Well,Well.Well,,,,,,The 49nders ran out of GAS.Did they THUNK we would lay down.After 4 Qu into overtime.PleaseNothin LEF'T.GO BIG BLUE...The  EAST COAST WAS ROCKI!!!!!!!!!!!MAYHEM FROM THE MEDOWLANDS>>>

Finally now that the Giants have gotten back into the Super Bowl we can quit hearing about Tebow...I live in Colorado Springs and am a hard core Giants fan even though I have lived here all my life...Thank you Giants...
Brown rice and sharp cheddar omelet - sounds weird, but it's delicious!

That must be Nordic Ware's microwave omelette pan at $3.50 from their website.  I have their microwave egg boiler and have never boiled eggs using a stove since.  Nordic Ware rules the microwave, and is American made.

I found even  better, cheaper and quicker method. Being in Target I found in kitchen ware for $3.98 a4-5 inch round microwave egg cooker for non-fried eggs such as scrambled or omelet that took i minute for preparation and 45-60 second microwaving then 1 minute to wash and store. VERY tasteful - fix one every 2 minutes so everyone can have a hot quick meal taylor made for each . Can add cheese/ bacon, ham, onions, peppers, spices or whatever merely increasing a few seconds longer !!! Voila !!!
Sounds delicious! My husband makes an omelet every morning and I'm always jealous. We found a great recipe for Southwest Taco soup thats incredibly easy. www.losingtogether.com

Egg omelets are my metaphor
For everything worth waiting for,
Jumbo eggs in the mix
Give me my tastebud fix,
Life without eggs I would deplore!
Then don't watch

jcfish -

Go find another city to berate, not the most beautiful city in the world. Your 'metaphysics' only creates vitriol.

It seems odd to lump beagles in with "short-legged, long-torso breeds of dogs, like dachshunds, corgis, Pekingese and Shih Tzus". Beagles always struck me as being reasonably well-proportioned. I think the real "cure" is not to breed such deliberately deformed dogs (including brachycephalic breeds such as pugs and bulldogs).

That is the most hideous photo of a dog in a wheelchair I have ever seen. It is poorly adjusted, and it is irresponsible for you to publish this particular photo. Perhaps this was done as a way of reaffirming that the only way to assist dogs with disabilities is to create new pharmaceuticals. I am the director of sales for a locally owned company that custom builds wheelchairs for disabled animals (not the one shown in the photo). When they are properly adjusted, they provide excellent mobility and independence for dogs, cats, and other animals.

CG
...or we could just stop breeding dogs for the very abnormality which predisposes them to ruptured discs.  Is a low-riding dog really worth it?

It is rare, which is why this collaboration is news.

The inhibited protein in this study is matrix metalloproteinase-9, on which there is only about 20 years of literature. MMP9 was identified with animal studies, as was the association of MMP9 with nerve damage. Synthesized MMP9 inhibitors were tested, and sometimes found to be lethally toxic, in animal studies. Still, there is no motherlode of data to be mined about what drugs safely and specifically inhibit MMP9 in spinal cord injuries, which is why work continues with dachshunds.

To argue that scientists should exclusively use experimental subjects with spontaneous injury or illness is unreasonable. The existence of such a cohort is fortuitous. But the number of subjects required; the need for standardization; the rounds of verification and calibration; the logistics of finding appropriate subjects are only met by breeding experimental subjects.The alternative is for studies to proceed with affected humans based only on the in vivo data that suggests investigative animal studies. To me, that would truly be unethical. It's what the FDA and IRBs exist to prevent.

There is an argument to be made that some use of animals should be eliminated, such as in dissection and anatomy labs where we know enough about the macrosystems to create detailed computer simulations. We are a long, long way from simulating whole biologic systems on the micro and nano scales. To do so, we would have to do a lot more animal experimentation.

Agree with you. Sad for Ali, hope she recovers well.
As for the back and forth between Brian and KOW: Canada took care of Cuba by a tidy 2-0 score. Running it up against a minnow always invites rash challenges. The higher the score, the higher the risk meter gets dialed up to. Perhaps it wasn't necessary for A-Rod to throw up a five spot in half an hour, especially since it was over at the half.
As a former girl's youth coach, there are lots of tactics to depress scoring to avoid embarrassment. You can insist on ten one touch passes before allowing the players to shoot, as an example. You can scramble positions on the field, so that center halves play in forward positions and forwards defend. 14-0 is quite frankly unseemly, and it doesn't reflect well on Pia. The eventual key matches are going to be measured by the ability of Boxx and Lloyd to control the midfield and to create chances. Yet to be tested, yet to know how this will go.
if the ambition is to win another gold medal, a match against a baseball playing minnow is determinative of nothing. Now it has cost the USWNT one of its top four defenders. Too bad.

A late cyber-acquaintance, a Philippine veterinary school professor, swore that he had cured dozens of spinally injured dogs by applying DMSO to the skin above the affected area of the spine soon after the injury.
Since you now lice in NY, do you realize that some of YOUR Federal tax dollars go to S. Carolina?   The get $1.35 for ever $1.00 they pay.

Off the top of my head my thought is this:I am from that part of the world and have lived in NY for awhile-Most Carolinians see themselves as rugged individualists and don't want government interference in their life (for example, I understand that the State recently banished car inspection requirements for natives of SC)-And, lets face it, the Democratic party is not exactly seen as the party of rugged individualists-(LOL as the kids say)-Also, many people, Southerners included, forget how anti-segrigationist the Southern Democrats were until fairly recently (which Prof. Shaw references, but fails to connect the dots)-

On another note I am a Republican and, no surprise, I am not taken with Obama and his failure has been of no particular surprise to me-It is amusing to see the liberal media attempting to save Obama's bacon with desperate articles like these explaining why the electorate has it all wrong...

Conservatives willingly bring the powers of the federal government to bear when state and local governments don't conform to their views on social and moral issues.  Although they say that they want a more limited federal government, they are more than willing to pass federal legislation that usurps the will of the people living in cities and states that pass legislation that does not conform to their views on morality.

Although I went to school in St. Louis and have traveled extensively throughout the South, I will never understand how drivel passes for intelligence there.  Of course everyone hates the government but celebrates the military in South Carolina.  Why bother with consistency.  And, then there's the abundant racism that proclaims how good things were for the house slaves!  Why they never would have become sharecroppers if they'd been allowed just to stay slaves!  Anachronistic, yes.  Stupid, absolutely.  South Carolina, in fact, much of the Southern United States is stuck on stupid and voting against their best interests.  Actually, it's all quite sad.

Unions protect bad teachers. That's their job. I don't recall campaigns by teachers unions to replace underperforming teachers to benefit children. We should either abolish teachers unions altogether or remove them entirely from any discussion about which teachers stay and which teachers go.

There are plenty of men out there who appreciate educated, accomplished women and even consider it a "feather in their cap" to be associated with them. Beyond where to go to meet such men (still a problem in this society!), the main issues for both halves of any couple in love continue to be mutual admiration, shared values, a major interest  or interests in common, and mutual respect and consideration. Race and class are unimportant if these other essentials are present.

Here is a serious question. Can you name a single nation that exemplifies the conservative economic values you advocate, now or at any time in history? One in which you'd be willing to live if it was a matter of a dice roll which social class you belonged to?

Liberals can name a great number of nations in the actual world which govern in such a way to benefit a majority of their citizens but I have yet to hear a good example of a fiscally conservative, small-government one. Switzerland? Guess what, they have mandatory, universal health care "shoved down their throats", the unfortunate people.

All this cant about the evils of big government is a distraction from the serious issues facing our nation today, about which we need to have real debate and discussion--wouldn't that be nice!

"Democrats believe in a smarter (and to a degree a smaller) federal government, "rules of the road" regulations over corporations and businesses so to ensure fairness in the free market and fair wages, and a balance in federalism that does not simply devolve most federal authority and responsibility to the state (whether the issue is social security, voting and civil rights or a women's right to choose). "  In what world do Democrats believe in small government?  They believe in a government run by liberal doctorates who have no real world experience. The "federal authority" that SC wants is the authority originally given it under the constitution and taken by Democrats to centralize our government.  Name a Democrat state that is in better shape than a Red State.  Get Serious.
